title: Guide to MongoDB on Ubuntu

heading.title: MongoDB
heading.heading: Here I will go through setting up MongoDB locally on an Ubuntu machine.
heading.heading2: To learn more about MongoDB, you can click

before.heading: This is what you need to have ready before you start.
before.step3: If you're wondering how to create a VM, you can click

video.title: Here is a video that goes through it.

commands.title: Here are the commands used in the video.
commands.sudo: 'Sudo' means 'superuser do,' and allows users to execute commands with elevated privileges.
commands.systemctl: Systemctl is a command in Unix/Linux systems used to manage system services, like starting, stopping, and restarting.
commands.echo: Echo is a command in Unix/Linux systems used to display a line of text or variable content in the terminal.

image1.title1: After you have followed the video above, you can see below to see how to connect to the database with javascript.
image1.title2: On the line where it says 'Connecting to:', is your database URI.
image1.title3: You'll need this when connecting to the database through javascript.

image2.alt: Connect to database with javascript and mongoose
image2.title: Here is an example of how to connect to the database with javascript and mongoose. I would recommend using mongoose over mongodb because it's easier to set up and easier to use.

image3.alt: Connect to database with javascript and mongodb
image3.title: Here is an example of how to connect to the database with javascript and mongodb.
